--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> Question: do you instantiate the class directly (using a
> creation method) or does some framework do it for you?
> 
> However the class is created, hide that behind an interface,
> which you can then mock.

[JBR makes some good points and asks the right question.]

You can build a Facade in front of the object you want to mock -- so 
that you can mock out the Facade object, which will often be simpler 
than the real object.

But the weakness to this approach is that if you're using a framework 
(a library that your classes extend, or which takes pointers to 
classes you want to mock), then to build a Facade for the framework, 
you'll discover that your Facade must be another complete framework, 
if it can be done at all.  Frameworks can be a real barrier to 
testing.


Another option:
Can you subclass the class in question?


Another option:
Digging *DEEP* into the bag of tricks, here's something to use when 
nothing else will work:  See Neil Swingler's javassist class loader 
in the Files section of this group:  
Name "name.swingler.neil.classreloader.zip", description "reloading 
classloader that can introduce imposter mock classes".  It will 
enable you to swap out the offending 3rd party class with one of your 
own making.

In a similar situation, I used jAdvise (which is built on top of 
javassist) to intercept and modify the internal behavior of the 3rd 
party class factory so that I could create instances of the class I 
wanted to test, intercept all method calls to it, and disable 
everything it did that had undesirable side effects, replacing method 
body functionality with my mock implementation.
